g.text: Yang et al. Prediction Vegetation Change With Traits
Projected vegetation patterns under different representative concentration pathways (RCPs) during three different periods.
vegetation area changes under RCP2.6, RCP4.5 and RCP8.5 compared with an historical vegetation map (
complex; (2) Subtropical forest complex; (3) Temperate forest complex; (4) Boreal and alpine forests; (5) Temperate scrub; (6) Temperate steppe; (7) Alpine steppe; (8)
). Compared with the leaf N concentration
as the sum of a metabolic component proportional to
photosynthetic capacity and a structural component proportional
to the leaf mass per area (LMA, LMA = 1/SLA) (
is a key variable for modeling because
it determines the N demand of leaf construction. This
variable is represented in many recent vegetation models
that include an interactive N cycle (
). The LES reﬂects the linkage between
high construction costs and long payback times of leaves
). More broadly, the LES is a universal feature
of functional diversity within communities (see e.g.,
The LAI, which is equally signiﬁcant to the LA, is expected to
increase with precipitation and temperature due to energy-
these constraints, leaf temperature is usually lower than air
temperature under warm, well-watered, mid-day conditions
higher than air temperature. At night, leaf temperature is
usually lower than air temperature. By specifying the lower
and upper thermal limits for leaf damage, we can predict
the maximum LA in any climate. LA is an important target
for modeling because (a) it contributes to the determination
of the temperature at which photosynthesis, respiration
and evaporation from the leaf surface take place, and (b)
it climatically determines shifts in leaf size that should
be linked to major changes in community composition.
Three traits are co-located and present trait covariations
eﬀectively, which is important information for balancing traits
This work highlights two challenges for modeling. The
ﬁrst is the “challenge of predictability” – the extent to
which trait values can be predicted from independent
information, including environmental factors and/or others.
Recent research has mainly focused on the prediction
of community-mean trait values. In fact, some trait
variation, even in such a climatically wide-ranging data
set, is not predictable by climate alone, and some other
factors, such as site microclimate, life form, and family
(phylogeny), are also important contributors to the trait
as a powerful control that allows empirical trait–climate
relationships derived from data in China to be applied globally
The second modeling challenge is the “challenge of functional
diversity.” Trait-based models can represent the co-existence
of multiple trait combinations. Moreover, this diversity
confers increased resilience in model communities in the
challenge is to ﬁnd a generally applicable method to specify
